repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - First, Second and Third
            Poverty Reduction Support Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the First Poverty Reduction
            Support Operations (PRSC I) for Madagascar are as follows:
            outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to the development
            outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also rated
            moderately satisfactory. Ratings for the Second Poverty
            Reduction Support Operations (PRSC II) for Madagascar are as
            follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to the
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was
            also rated satisfactory. Ratings for the Third Poverty
            Reduction Support Operations (PRSC III) for Madagascar are
            as follows: outcome was moderately satisfactory, risk to the
            development outcome was moderate, the Bank performance was
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also rated
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1) PRSCs I-III
            rightly focused on the critical areas of public finance
            management and human development. Future PRSCs may want to
            deepen support in these areas and focus on critical
            bottlenecks rather than broadening the areas of support to
            new areas. It may also be important to identify the
            institutional and absorptive capacities of each sector, to
            provide budget support to those sectors with the highest
            capacities and to use PRSCs in combination with sectoral
            projects to those areas where capacities are lowest. 2) The
            amount provided under the form of budget support has been
            revised downward for a better balance of overall Bank
            support between budget support and projects. The next series
            of PRSCs which would consist of three annual operations for
            US$40 million each seems to strike an adequate balance.
            Increase in budget support could be linked to credible and
            sustained improvement in revenue collection, civil service,
            and public sector management systems. 3) Both the Bank and
            the Government need to have realistic expectations about the
            breadth and pace of reform implementation. In particular,
            the political appetite for reforms must be aligned with the
            country's technical capacity to implement and absorb
            these reforms.

repnme.cdata!:
Madagascar - Poverty Reduction Support
            Operation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Madagascar Poverty Reduction Support
            Operation Project had a moderately satisfactory outcome,
            likely sustainability, substantial institutional
            development, overall satisfactory Bank performance, and
            overall moderately satisfactory Borrower performance. Some
            implications for subsequent operations are: The first year
            of implementation demonstrated the need for continued and
            increased support for public and financial management
            reforms. In particular, increase efforts to strengthen and
            build capacity in the sector ministries for budget
            formulation, procurement, and financial management. Greater
            realism is needed in setting targets and the timeframe.
            Prioritize and scale up the reform process to match the
            Government's capacity. Unpredictability in resource
            flows seriously hampered budget execution during 2004;
            improve predictability through better revenue forecasting. A
            better alignment of donor disbursements with the budget
            cycle might also help improve predictability. A firm
            commitment is actually more relevant than the timing of the
            disbursement; in the case of Madagascar, however, the
            resource availability at the outset is critical in providing
            the level of confidence and certainty needed to execute the
            budget and avoid stop-and-go cycles.

5065030.majtheme: Public sector governance,Environment and natural resource management,Rural development,Human development

abstracts.cdata!:
A series of three single tranche Poverty
            Reduction Support Credits (PRSCs), that will be provided in
            the form of budget support, is envisaged to support
            implementation of the Poverty Reduction Strategy Paper
            (PRSP). PRSC 1 will support the strategic axes of good
            governance (public expenditure management and
            anti-corruption), and promoting human development through
            improved service delivery in education and nutrition. In
            addition, strengthening monitoring and evaluation will lead
            to an enhanced accountability and results focus.  PRSC
            's support includes assistance to the Government in
            implementing its 2004 Priority Action Plan for public
            expenditure management reforms. This includes the
            preparation and submission to Parliament of the public
            finance framework law; improved alignment of the 2004 budget
            to the priorities of the PRSP, the reform of the Treasury,
            simplification of expenditure management process, the
            development and submission to Parliament of a new
            Procurement Code, and strengthening internal controls
            through the establishment of a General Inspectorate for
            Finances. PRSC 1 also supports the Government's
            anti-corruption agenda, including establishment of an
            operational Anti- Corruption Commission and the development
            of a national anti-corruption strategy. PRSC 1 also supports
            Axis 3 on providing human and material security, by
            supporting the development and implementation of the
            Government's Education for All Agenda and service
            delivery in nutrition. Key policy reforms have included an
            increase in the education budget, measures to decrease
            education costs for poor households (suppression of school
            fees, provision of learning materials to all primary
            students), actions to increase access for poor students
            (through school construction, salary compensation for
            teachers paid by parents, teacher recruitment) and
            reinforcement of management capacity at central and
            decentralized levels. PRSC 1 also supports policy and
            institutional reform in the nutrition sector. The Country
            Financial Accountability Assessment (2003) and the Country
            Procurement Assessment Report (CPAR, 2003), and the draft
            Public Expenditure Review (PER) provide the analytical
            underpinnings for the public sector reform agenda supported
            by this PRSC, and background work for the Education for All
            underpins reforms in this area. A supporting Technical
            Assistance Credit (Good Governance and Institutional
            Development) approved in November 2003 will assist the
            government in putting in place the systems to strengthen
            budget management, and finance technical assistance and
            capacity building needs. The credit would be disbursed in
            one tranche at effectiveness following effectiveness.
